--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
>Dere=
k and Philip on this group both 
> did that and have published late breakin=
g papers at GECCO.  They 
> have experience in trying to publish without ac=
ademic affiliation, 
> so they may be able to give you some perspective.  
=
> 
> Note that the main barrier to independent publishing in research is 
>=
 not lack of affiliation.  In my opinion, it is style.  

Yes, I think Ken =
is probably right here.  If you really want to 
publish, as with any kind o=
f writing, it's important to be well-read in 
the literature, and to be fam=
iliar with the approach and style, as well 
as with previous research.

We =
submitted a couple of papers to journals, and I think one of our big 
probl=
ems was simply lack of depth of knowledge in a particular area.  
With all =
of these issues, it helps if you have an advisor of some sort, 
someone who=
 *has* published, to critique and help you improve your work.

Part of our =
problem honestly was access to some of the literature.  I'm 
a student now =
at UL Lafayette, and I have free access to just about any 
journal article =
I want to read.  I was limited to what I could find 
freely through CiteSee=
r or Google Scholar before.  Books were not a 
problem, but journal article=
s definitely were.  And now I also have 
that critical infrastructure of pr=
ofessors who have published who can 
provide me critical feedback.

So whil=
e I don't think it's impossible to publish outside the academic 
framework,=
 there are definitely a number of issues that make it more 
difficult.

Der=
ek
